text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Harriet May Stuck.
Present Address: Abernethy Sask.
Pioneer Address: Abernethy Assn. W.T.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1876

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realise that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?
   How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? not on Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?
   What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day or in the afternoon, etc.? mostly afternoon some times for noon meal and home again before dark.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? yes

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? yes, often

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst driven or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? At Christmas nearly every family held a house party.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first five years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

How many of these were bachelor or bachelorette homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Yes or No?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was your visiting done without an invitation? Usually or rarely?

5. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

6. Did you ever have "hoes" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes or No?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, what drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Our parties were all house parties. We danced and played games.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a month, etc.?

At Christmas nearly every family had a house party.
2. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Some times the school was used for social affairs, not much, as it was a small school.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Most of our picnic ball games were around somebody's home.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1920.

What material was it made of? Brick. How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community as a war-benefit.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In Town.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Yes.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? Yes.

What dances were popular? Waltz, Square dances.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Yes by some people but card playing was pretty much general.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school questionnaires.) Give dates.

Some answers:

The school was used for social affairs, not much, as it moved around some body here.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1920.

What material was it made of? Brick

How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special clubs, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community as a whole

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In Town

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? For example, did you attend parties in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for all social gatherings and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question B, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? Waltz, Square dance,

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who favored upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

You by some people but card playing was pretty much ignored
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?  

There was a good deal of form and attention paid to what was considered proper.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?  

Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Chivarees in our district were almost unknown. There were a few I do think was here at one.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?  

Yes

When was it organized? Not sure, 1914 or thereabouts.

Approximately how many women belonged to it? Twenty.

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

The Homemakers did a really worthwhile work helping the sick or those in need of help bring in good entertainers such as Rich Reid. In fact, I think it was perhaps the best organized women's club the town ever had.
3. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Yes

4. When was it organized? 1914

5. Approximately how many women belonged to it? Twenty

6. Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

The Homemakers did a really worthwhile work helping the sick or those in need of help such as filling in for interlaborers such as Richland County. In fact, I think the town never had an organization like this before.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people from an one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In the homes or the Town Hall

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Yes there were special speakers.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
In the Room

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

21. What games did boys play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

22. What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as rummy, pinochle, whist, or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bone, stone, beads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PIONEER AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?
   What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Name the different kinds of food which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

That year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes When was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?

I think so
40. What did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Then was the sports day usually held? (first month, or any special day, such as July 4th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known literary clubs or other similar? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can by many names still thought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many? (The books used in the early years will be good to do.)

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?

I think so
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it
   contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian,
   and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to
    the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped cer-
    tain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading
    material? Yes
    Give dates and tell how and where you got them.
    I couldn't say but I do remember seeing them as a child.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
    I haven't any but I think my brothers have unless they have been lost.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your
    early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
    There wasn't a great deal of literature but what was there was good to those who wished
    to read there was perhaps enough.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, its size, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the Cree monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

There was a great deal of literature but what was there was good to hear and wished to read there was perhaps enough.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
   Organs, pianos, violins.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   We had an organ, then a piano.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   Singing and music played a large part in our homes, often whole evenings were spent in singing hymn songs.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
   Annie Laurie, Robin Adair, Slow gently sweet often, Build large fires men & families etc.

in the community?
   Much the same songs were sung.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.
   Yes.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   Yes, sometimes.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started?
   Who started it? How long did it continue?

   How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

   What instruments were included?
   The Band came later.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
   I really don't know much about the band it played for years ago, picnics.
56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your house entertainments in early years in the West? Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the house? (Examples: "Home Sweet Home," "Dixie," "The Old Folks at Home," etc.)

61. Was there a band or orchestra in the community? If so, describe.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? If so, when was it started? How long did it continue?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

I usually don't know much about the band. It played for your day picnics.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Music is not as important now as in the earlier days. I would say.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

I have always been interested in collecting stories about arrowheads. I have given most of them to people with collections by later years. I've given more of my things to young people who were interested in that sort of thing.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

Although I've always been interested in weather and birds, I've never made any records of them.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I have a small library and I also have done a little watercolor sketching. Walking and reading are my favorite pastimes.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

Ralph Stuck and Leonard Thompson

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

In looking back to the early years, we did put forth an effort to enjoy and make use of the cultural things such as music. One winter, we joined people whom we could meet and study Shakespeare. Perhaps another time it would be something else... good.
Hobbies and Special Interests

64. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, etc.? If so, describe them.

65. In what area do you feel most interested? What is the reason for this interest?

66. Have you ever been interested in collecting stones or minerals? If so, explain.

67. Have you ever been interested in birds, flowers, or butterflies? If so, explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music, or extra business (if necessary).

In looking back over the early years, I did put forth an effort to enjoy and make use of the cultural things such as music, art, movies, and clubs. Perhaps another time it would be something else...
pictures. Our ministers most of whom were from the old country did a lot towards keeping in that line. One Scotch parson had a lot of copies of great paintings and would tell us the story of the painting he gave them away to the children. I still have one he gave me. He also used to get the "Penny Pictures." Our teachers also did much in that way for the prairie children. I don't wish to be critical but I do feel there is a great lack of interest in those things among so many of our young people today.

Mattie M. Ulrich.
Pictures. Our memories most often come from the old country and a trip towards Europe in my time. Our search papers for a story and would expire. Great paintings and novels free us the story for the children. I can them away. But have one he gave me he also used to get the penny pictures. Our school also did much in that way.

For the prairie children I don't know to be critical but I do feel there is a great lack of culture among so many of our young people today.

Patti M. Quick
Oxford.
No. 613 S
